RESIGNATION OF MEMBERS
(Announcement by Mr Speaker)


    Mr Speaker: Order. I have to inform hon. Members that at 10.30 a.m. on the 18th of October, 1966, I received to hand a letter dated the 4th October, 1966, under the hand of Dr Fong Kim Heng, who was elected to this House as Member for Joo Chiat, resigning his seat in Parliament. Members will recall that Dr Fong has been ill and has had to apply for periods of leave. In view of his continued ill-health Dr Fong states that he feels it his duty to resign his seat. Dr Fong's letter was received in my office on the 4th of October, 1966.

    I further have to inform hon. Members that at 10.30 a.m. on the 18th of October, 1966, I received to hand a letter dated the 8th of October, 1966, signed by Mr Chia Thye Poh who was elected to this House as Member for Jurong. This letter was delivered to my office on the 8th of October, 1966. The material part of this letter reads as follows:-

    "...the Party" (i.e, the Barisan Sosialis) "has decided that all Barisan 'MPs' will resign their 'Parliamentary' seats as from today.

    The 9 Barisan MPs are:-

    1. Chia Thye Poh (Jurong)

    2. Koo Young (Thomson)

    3. Ong Lian Teng (Bukit Panjang)

    4. Poh Ber Liak (Tampines)

    5. Tan Cheng Tong (Jalan Kayu)

    6. Miss Loh Miaw Gong (Havelock)

    7. Chan Sun Wing (Nee Soon)

    8. Lee Tee Tong (Bukit Timah)

    9. Wong Soon Fong (Toa Payoh)".

Column: 343

I had to consider the effect of this letter in the light of the Constitution, in particular, of Article 30 (2) (c) which provides that -

    'The seat of a Member of Parliament shall become vacant, if, by writing under his hand addressed to the Speaker, he resigns his seat in Parliament;'.

    In view of another letter I have received from Mr Lee Tee Tong, who was elected to this House as Member for Bukit Timah, what I say hereafter on Mr Chia's letter has no reference to Mr Lee Tee Tong.

    I have given Mr Chia Thye Poh's letter considerable thought in view of the particular circumstances affecting certain of the Members named in the letter. To my mind, the provisions of Article 30 (2) (c) are clear and preclude resignation by an agent. Any resignation to be effective must, amongst other requirements, be by writing under the hand of the Member concerned and of no one else. I have, therefore, come to the conclusion that the letter signed by Mr Chia Thye Poh is ineffective for its expressed purpose in so far as the following 7 persons are concerned:-

    (1) Mr Koo Young - Member for Thomson

    (2) Mr Ong Lian Teng - Member for Bukit Panjang

    (3) Mr Poh Ber Liak - Member for Tampines

    (4) Mr Tan Cheng Tong - Member for Jalan Kayu

    (5) Miss Loh Miaw Gong - Member for Havelock

    (6) Mr Chan Sun Wing - Member for Nee Soon

    (7) Mr Wong Soon Fong - Member for Toa Payoh.

    Mr Chia Thye Poh's own position caused me further difficulty in that, although the letter was under his hand and was addressed to me, he did not, in so many words, "resign his seat". However, after studying the matter and giving it considerable thought, I have come to the clear conclusion that Mr Chia Thye Poh's personal intention was to resign his seat and that he has adequately given effect to that intention by

Column: 344

signing that letter addressed to me in the terms in which it was written and by causing that letter to be delivered to me.

    I also have to inform hon. Members that at 10.30 a.m. on the 18th of October, 1966, I received to hand a letter dated the 4th of October, 1966, under the hand of Mr Lee Tee Tong, who was elected to this House as Member for Bukit Timah, resigning his seat in Parliament. This letter was received in my office on the 14th of October, 1966.

    Under the provisions of Article 91(4) , the resignations of Dr Fong Kim Heng, Mr Chia Thye Poh and Mr Lee Tee Tong have effect from 10.30 a.m, on the 18th of October, 1966.

    Accordingly, I report to the House that the seats of the Members for Joo Chiat, Jurong and Bukit Timah are vacant.

ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

NON-SINGAPORE CITIZENS
(Entry into Singapore)


    1. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Deputy Prime Minister if he will consider permitting the entry into Singapore of non-Singapore citizens over the age of, say, 60 years whose sponsors can adequately provide for them.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Speaker, Sir, the existing rule is that widows of 65 years and above and widowers of 70 years and above will be considered for admission into Singapore. I am prepared to revise this rule by including widowers who are 65 years and above. However, the Government has examined the question of whether the age limit should be lowered to 60 years and has come to the conclusion that, for the moment, it would be inadvisable indeed to permit immigration of aged people below 65 years.

    Mr Speaker, the House is aware that as a little island State, it is very necessary indeed that we should exercise a firm immigration policy. Otherwise, faced with our own population expansion together with an influx from other territories, we might in the near future

Column: 345

be encumbered with considerable social problems.

    I would like, for the information of the Member, to tell him that last year a total of 26 applications were approved and this year, from January to September, a total of 39 applications have been approved. The majority of applications which were rejected were mainly because the applications referred to those who were below 65 years old. Another major reason was that the applicant was living with other children either in China or in India, and therefore could not be considered.

    I may also further emphasise that this regulation concerning admission of aged parents into Singapore refers expressly to widows or widowers and that these persons should provide full evidence that they have no other means of support if they are not permitted to enter Singapore. I can assure the Member, as I have done at the last sitting, that all applications are considered on compassionate grounds but, at the same time, we have also got to be fair not only to ourselves but to the State so that we do not see that Singapore is encumbered with unnecessary social problems.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)(In Mandarin): A supplementary question, Sir.

    I would like to ask the Minister concerned this question. In my constituency there is a resident who is a citizen of Singapore and who has a mother of over 60 years of age in China. Several years ago he made a request for her to come to Singapore but it was not approved. The reason was that he had a relative in China to support her. The complaint of this resident is that this relative of his mother in China has already been transferred to another place in China. So I would like to ask whether the Minister will reconsider this application.

    Mr Speaker: I do not know whether the Minister can answer that without notice.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Yes, Mr Speaker. If the Member will give me the name of

Column: 346

the applicant, the reference number of the letter which he received or which his constituent received from the Controller of Immigration, I will look into the matter. But I must emphasise to him that there must be absolute proof that there is nobody in China who could look after the applicant. The Member has forgotten that the ruling applies only to widows who are 65 years old and above, and if she happens to be 62 years old, then I am afraid she is not covered by this regulation and therefore cannot be granted admission.

KEBUN UBI COMMUNITY CENTRE AT JALAN PENGGAGA

WOMEN IN SINGAPORE POLICE FORCE


    3. Madam Chan Choy Siong asked the Minister of Defence whether it is Government policy that women could and should also share in the task of safeguarding the security of our young Republic and whether he will take immediate steps to create more opportunities for them to serve in the Police Force.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, it is the Government's policy that women should share in the task of safeguarding the security of our young Republic. They take a rightful place in the ranks of both the Police and the Army. The number of policewomen required is, however,

Column: 347

limited by the fact that in the field of criminal activity, particularly where violence is used, women have not yet achieved equality with men. Therefore, it is necessary to employ more policemen than policewomen.

    Similarly, in the Army, women cannot be used as combat troops, but they are usefully engaged in clerical, nursing and communications work.

    Madam Chan Choy Siong (Delta)(In Mandarin): Sir, can I supplement my question? If there are posts at present which need women to come forward to serve the country, especially posts in the Police Force, will the Minister consider providing women with these facilities? According to him, certain posts are not quite suitable for women, but I understand that in the Police Force, certain posts are quite suitable for women. Will he consider providing better facilities for women to join the Police Force?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, at present the number of posts in the establishment of policewomen is something like 245 - in that order of magnitude - I have not got the actual figure. Most of these posts are filled. There are only a few vacancies, possibly about half a dozen. These will be filled in the normal course of work.

EAST EUROPEAN COMMUNIST COUNTRIES
(Setting up of Embassies or Trade Representations)


    4. Mr Chow Chiok Hock asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs whether the Government intends to set up embassies or trade representations in East European Communist Countries.

    Mr S. Rajaratnam: The Member for Ulu Pandan will recall my statement to this House on the 16th and 17th of December last year in which I said that it was our intention first to establish Missions in some ten countries. At that time, I also mentioned that it was our intention to set up other Missions when we can find the personnel and the money or when political and trade considerations justify their being set up earlier.

Column: 348



    It is in such context that the establishment of Embassies or trade representations in East European countries will have to be viewed.

    However, I would like to assure the Member for Ulu Pandan that promotion of trade with as many countries as possible regardless of ideological differences, whether they are in the East or in the West, still remains a major objective of our foreign policy. These intentions have been embodied in the trade agreements recently concluded with the U.S.S.R., Bulgaria and Poland, which provide for the establishment of Singapore trade representations in those countries in the future.

HIGH COMMISSIONS AND EMBASSIES
(Personnel and expenditure)


    5. Mr Chow Chiok Hock asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs (a) to date, how many High Commissions and Embassies have been set up and in which countries; (b) how many personnel for diplomatic service have been recruited; and (c) what is the annual expenditure for High Commissions and Embassies.

    Mr Rajaratnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, I informed this House in December last year that it was the intention of the Government to establish diplomatic missions before the end of the year in ten countries.

    As of now, diplomatic missions have been established in the following countries: Australia, Cambodia, Malaysia, New Zealand, Thailand and the United Kingdom. In addition, a permanent mission to the United Nations has been established in New York. It is hoped that before the end of the year, diplomatic missions will also be established in India, the United Arab Republic and possibly Japan.

    As regards the second part of the question, the Public Service Commission has so far recruited four new entrants, and in addition approved the secondment of eight senior officers from different branches of the home civil service for service in overseas missions. These

Column: 349

figures do not, of course, include the heads of missions nor do they include Division II officers serving in overseas missions.

    As regards the third part of the question on annual expenditure, last year this House voted a sum of $� million for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. This sum was spent on setting up the Ministry itself and two overseas missions - one in Kuala Lumpur and the other in New York. This year, a sum of $4 million has been voted. However, since most of the overseas missions were not fully established until the middle of this year, the expenditure for the first half of the year was below the expected average. Members will appreciate that until the missions have been fully in existence for at least a year, it will not be possible to give reliable estimates of the annual expenditure.

PAYA LEBAR
(Integrated Secondary and Secondary Technical Schools)


    6. Mr Tay Boon Too asked the Minister for Education whether an integrated Secondary School and a Secondary Technical School will be built in the Paya Lebar Constituency.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, there are no plans for the building of secondary schools in the Paya Lebar Constituency under the Second Plan.

    The International Airport takes up a quarter of the area covered by this constituency. Whilst the remaining areas are densely settled, it has not been possible to acquire a suitable site within this constituency for development into a secondary school, and the residents living in this constituency are being served by secondary schools in the neighbouring areas. One secondary school is being built at Lowland Road, whilst construction work on another secondary school in Mount Vernon Road will begin shortly. These two secondary schools are just outside the boundary of the Paya Lebar Constituency and within

Column: 350

    The point I would like to raise is that I regret that the Minister for Education does not see fit to set up the secondary schools as requested by me. There are quite a number of residents in this constituency. If there are not enough secondary schools, then -

    Mr Tay Boon Too(In Mandarin): Thank you for your direction, Sir. It is very clear that if there is no integrated secondary school in the Paya Lebar Constituency, then it will be a great inconvenience to the residents.

    The point is that in the Paya Lebar Constituency, there are no means of communication, no crossroads, not even pirate taxis. Under such conditions, it is very difficult for the residents to send their children to schools outside the constituency. So I feel that it is rather inconvenient in respect of time and other -

UNIVERSITY OF SINGAPORE
(Government's financial contribution for 1966)


    7. Mr P. Govindaswamy asked the Minister for Education what is the Government's financial contribution to the University of Singapore for 1966; and whether he will obtain and give a breakdown of how the contribution is expended.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government's financial contribution to the University of Singapore for 1966 is $10 million. Of this amount, about $9 million is for Personal Emoluments, the balance for honoraria, departmental grants, new equipment and other items of recurrent expenditure.

PAYA LEBAR
(Outpatient Dispensary)

INSTITUTE OF RESEARCH ON PROBLEMS OF WOMEN


    11. Madam Chan Choy Siong asked the Minister for Culture and Social Affairs whether he intends setting up an institute of research on problems of women, as outlined in "The Tasks Ahead, 1959", with a view to improving their social, economic and political status in society.

    Inche Othman Bin Wok: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government has since 1959 introduced various measures which have considerably improved the status of women in Singapore, including the enactment of the Women's Charter, 1960, which, among other things, enforces monogamy in Singapore except for Muslims, and the institution of equal pay for women in the civil service. The problems of women therefore no longer constitute an urgent issue as it used to be in the old days. There is no reference to the setting up of an Institute of Research on the Problems of Women in The Tasks Ahead, 1959-1964 - at least in the English copies. However, the desirability of setting up a research institute to study these problems will be looked into by my Ministry.

KAMPONG POTONG PASIR
(Assistance to farmers to combat pests)


    12. Mr S. V. Lingam asked the Minister for Law and National Development whether he has received any requests from farmers of Kampong Potong Pasir and the surrounding areas for assistance to combat pests damaging their vegetables and what action has been taken in the matter.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development (Mr Ho Cheng Choon) (for the Minister for Law and National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, there was a serious outbreak of pest infestation in vegetable farms in Kampong Potong Pasir recently, The pest was identified as Diamond-Back moth. In early 1965 this species attacked vegetable farms in Changi and Punggol, but with the assistance rendered by the officers of the Primary Production Department, these farms soon became free from infestation. In March 1966 the Diamond-Back moth appeared in large numbers in and around Kampong Potong Pasir. Teams of Primary Production officers were immediately despatched to the scene to help combat the pest. They discovered that the farmers there had been indiscriminately

Column: 355

spraying their vegetable crops with all types of insecticides which proved to be ineffective, because the pests had developed a resistance to such insecticides. The problem was further aggravated because the Potong Pasir farmers, owing to economic considerations, were unwilling to adopt crop rotation which is one reliable method of pest control and, in fact, has proved effective in combatting the same pests in Changi and Punggol.

    On the advice of the Primary Production Department, many farmers in Potong Pasir have now agreed to adopt rotation of the crops. As a result, the extent of the damage caused by the insect has been considerably reduced. The Department has also recommended to farmers the use of the moth alluring lights trap at night to kill as many moths as possible. In addition, by carrying out extensive experiments and field trials, the Department has found an organo phosphorus insecticide sold under the trade name "Phospherin" which is effective against the Diamond-Back moth. Orders for this effective insecticide have been placed with overseas companies, and sufficient quantities are expected to arrive very shortly.

Column: 356



    The Primary Production Department has also carried out film shows, lectures and discussions with farmers to acquaint them with the latest information and techniques in agricultural pest controls and eradication. The Department has also helped the affected farmers to obtain social welfare aid to overcome their temporary hardship.

    The pest infestation at Kampong Potong Pasir, though not completely removed, has been minimised to a great extent. It is expected that with the massive use of the organo phosphorus insecticide after its arrival, the pests will be wiped out.

ABATTOIRS IN SERANGOON, KATONG AND BUKIT PANJANG


    14. Mr S. Rajoo asked the Minister for Law and National Development if he will consider setting up Government abattoirs in the Serangoon, Katong and Bukit Panjang Districts to facilitate the slaughter of pigs and other live-stock for the people of those areas for sale at rural markets.

    Mr Ho Cheng Choon (for the Minister for Law and National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are in existence three abattoirs in Singapore - a pig abattoir in French Road, a cattle abattoir in Jalan Besar, and a sheep and goat abattoir also in Jalan Besar, opposite the cattle abattoir. The numbers of animals slaughtered in these abattoirs at present are about 1,200 pigs, 200 goats or sheep, and 30 heads of cattle each day.

    A new modern abattoir is being built in Jurong. This new abattoir will be highly mechanised and operated on a mechanised system, so that about 200 pigs, 100 goats or sheep and 15 heads of cattle can be slaughtered per hour. The slaughtering and meat inspection in the new abattoir will be of internationally accepted standards so that we can issue veterinary certificates acceptable to most countries to enable Singapore meat products to be marketed in foreign countries.

    The abattoir is being constructed at the cost of about $5 million and is expected to be completed in July 1967. On completion, the new abattoir, together with the existing ones, should be sufficient or adequate to meet the needs of the whole island. However, if

Column: 357

they prove to be insufficient or inadequate, every consideration will be given to build more abattoirs and to site them in the rural areas.
